titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the George and Joan Violin Collection
1950, 1994, undated
PR 338
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Larry Weimer

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-09-05T13:24-0400

did.unittitle: George A. and Joan G. Violin collection
did.abstract: The collection includes the work of photographers Louis Faurer (1916-2001) and Arnold Newman (1918-2006) and artist Vincent D. Smith (1929-2003). Faurer is represented by four images from 1950s New York City; Newman by eight undated portraits; and Smith by a signed suite of prints of eight of his etchings from 1965-1966 concerning African-American life and racial animosity.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged by artist.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to qualified researchers by appointment only.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to reproduce any Print Room holdings through publication must be obtained from: Rights and Reproductions The New-York Historical Society 170 Central Park West New York, NY 10024 Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 270 Fax: (212) 579-8794.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
acqinfo.p: Gift of George A. and Joan G. Violin, 2016 and 2017.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation Note
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the George A. and Joan G. Violin collection, PR 338, Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections, The New-York Historical Society.
Credit line: Gift of George A. and Joan G. Violin

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by archivist Larry Weimer in August 2017.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: The collection includes the work of photographers Louis Faurer (1916-2001) and Arnold Newman (1918-2006) and artist Vincent D. Smith (1929-2003). Faurer is represented by four images from 1950s New York City; Newman by eight undated portraits; and Smith by a signed suite of prints of eight of his etchings from 1965-1966 concerning African-American life and racial animosity. Further details on the individual photographs and the suite of etchings are detailed below in the container list.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes four gelatin silver prints of images taken in New York City. The container list includes titles and other details as recorded by the curator of N-YHS's Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Printed 1980; signed & titled on verso in graphite Louis Faurer; verso in graphite – lower left, circled “152”; verso lower center “PF109137”; verso lower right “20.17”; sheet: 10 7/8 x 13 7/8”; image: 8 x 11 1/4”.

did.unittitle: San Genaro Festival, New York, NY

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes eight gelatin silver prints of portraits. The container list includes titles and other details as recorded by the curator of N-YHS's Department of Prints, Photographs, and Architectural Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents Note
scopecontent.p: Includes a cased suite of etchings printed on Arches paper in 1994 by Kelly Driscoll at the Printmaking Workshop under the supervision of Robert Blackburn and the artist. Suite is number 27/40. Pages signed by artist and noted AP. Published by G.W. Einstein Company, Inc. The etchings are titled "Dispossess," Shadows in Harlem," The Man in Harlem," "Mississippi Incident," "Down on the Farm," "First Day of School," "Housing Northern[?] Style," and "The Long Hot Summer."
